TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , counsel for the applicant launched his own inquiries about the whereabouts of Captain PERSON he unsuccessfully attempted to reach him at the phone number which was listed in the interview record , and subsequently , on CARDINAL May and DATE , he asked the head of ORG of the GPE Police to confirm in writing that Captain PERSON was or had been one of their employees . CARDINAL . On DATE LOC delivered judgment . It found the applicant and PERSON guilty of selling a forged promissory note and sentenced the applicant to DATE and QUANTITY months’ imprisonment in a high - security correctional colony . In finding the applicant guilty , ORG referred to the following testimonies by witnesses :

“ The witness [ Major ] Kr . of ORG of the South - Western Department of ORG testified in court that on DATE he and Officer PERSON had taken part in the apprehension of individuals who had been suspected of being involved in the sale of forged securities . At TIME . and PERSON sat in Room CARDINAL in the PERSON hotel ... After they received information that the seller of the forged note had been detained , they went to Room CARDINAL where they saw PERSON whom they had not met previously . PERSON . had put questions to PERSON , and it followed from PERSON ’s replies , which were given without any pressure , that PERSON had sold a forged promissory note ... for MONEY and that the note itself and the money had stayed on the table ... PERSON . explained that he had examined the crime scene and seized the note and the money ...

It was established that this person was PERSON ... It was decided to carry out a ‘ controlled purchase’ , in which PERSON was to pose as the ‘ purchaser’ ... PERSON was asked to procure a promissory note having the nominal value of MONEY for PERCENT of its nominal value , that is MONEY . The money was examined , numbers on the banknotes were recorded , and MONEY was entrusted to the witness P. Two rooms , DATE and CARDINAL , were booked in the PERSON hotel located at ... The sale was to take place at TIME on DATE . According to the approved legend , P ... was in the car parked at the hotel . He then came up to the room where NORP and PERSON were waiting ; the note sat on the table . P. put the money onto the table ; without counting the money , PERSON threw it into a bag and put it onto the table next to him . At this moment police officers entered the room and arrested PERSON A report on the examination of the crime scene was compiled which P. countersigned . ”

CARDINAL . ORG further referred to written evidence which included PERSON ’s arrest record , the decision to carry out a “ controlled purchase ” , the report on the “ controlled purchase ” , the reports on examination of the money , the note and inspection of the crime scene , and the forensic expert ’s report indicating that the note had been a forgery .
CARDINAL . ORG also examined the transcripts of audio- and video - recordings and noted as follows :

“ The report on examination of LAW . CARDINAL videocassette , dated DATE , and the transcript of the conversation confirm the textual identity of the conversation which ORG had in the hotel room on DATE , with the previous transcript of DATE ( pp . CARDINAL - CARDINAL vol . CARDINAL ) .

The report of CARDINAL DATE concerns the examination of the EMTEC PERSON videocassette which was lawfully made available to the investigation ; it confirms the factual contents of the audio- and video - recordings , from which it follows that it was the defendant Mr PERSON who had given the envelope to PERSON in the driver ’s seat of the ORG car . The court has verified this circumstance and , contrary to the position of the defence , the court considers that the videocassette clearly shows that the envelope had been given to PERSON by Mr Ilyadi ( pp . CARDINAL vol . CARDINAL ) . ”
CARDINAL . ORG finally gave an overall assessment of evidence and established the defendants’ guilt in the following manner :

“ Assessing the testimonies by the witnesses PERSON . and PERSON , the court sees no reason to distrust them because they are concordant with the body of evidence presented by the prosecution and because they are mutually complementary and consistent . The court has not established any indication that those witnesses may have slandered the defendant [ sic , in singular ] . For the same reasons the court relied upon the statement by the witness PERSON which was read out in court . The court does not find any gross breaches by the investigation of the requirements of LAW during the pre - trial inquiry which may have led to declaring the above evidence inadmissible .

Contrary to the arguments by the defence , the court considers that the above body of evidence proves that both the defendant PERSON and the defendant Mr Ilyadi have been involved into the crime . On the basis of the conversation that took place during the meeting between PERSON and the ‘ purchaser’ , the pre - trial statement by the witness P. , the video - recording which was transcribed and examined in court and which showed that it had been Mr PERSON who had handed over the envelope to PERSON , the court is firmly convinced , rather than merely supposes , that Mr ORG envelope had contained a forged promissory note which had been given on DATE to PERSON near the PERSON hotel . [ The court also takes into account ] the body of evidence in its entirety , including in particular , the conduct by the defendants which unambiguously showed that they feared arrest , and the fact that both PERSON and Mr Ilyadi were aware that the note was a forgery . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted a short statement of appeal to the registry of ORG which indicated his intention to submit a detailed statement of appeal upon receipt of the judgment . According to the established NORP practice , statements of appeal must be filed with the registry of the first - instance court that gave judgment , which then would forward it to the appeal court .

CARDINAL . On DATE counsel for the applicant asked the head of ORG the GPE Police to confirm whether PERSON was currently or in the past listed in the staff records . By a letter of DATE , the head of ORG replied that “ PERSON was ] not listed in the records of ORG ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sent a detailed statement of appeal through the correspondence department of the remand centre to the registry of ORG . He complained , in particular , that there were deficiencies in the evidentiary base :

“ The investigation listed CARDINAL witnesses for the prosecution . CARDINAL of them were the attesting witnesses who had been present during PERSON arrest ... CARDINAL others were the police officers who had taken part in the controlled purchase of the forged promissory notes . Lieutenant - Colonel PERSON and Major PERSON . appeared in court and testified that I had not been the target of the operational measures and that they had not previously known me or heard about me ...

Only the statement made by the third police officer , PERSON , indicates my indirect connection with the crime . PERSON did not appear in court during the trial . This delayed the proceedings , because the prosecution insisted on having P. examined in court . A suspicion arose that PERSON may never have existed , and it was confirmed by the research carried out by my advocate ... He dialled the phone number listed in the statement and made sure that he reached the correct office . However , he heard that there was no employee by the name of P. and never had been . We prepared CARDINAL written inquiries for the director of ORG , to which he gave evasive replies ... The applicant asked the appeal court that his conviction be declared unlawful and quashed . He enclosed the replies his counsel had received from ORG the Moscow Police .
CARDINAL . By letter of DATE , the President of ORG asked the applicant to resubmit his statement of appeal as the original one had been lost . The applicant did as requested .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE City Court heard the appeal . The applicant was present before the appeal court and made oral submissions . According to him , of his written submissions , only the resubmitted short statement of appeal , but not the detailed one , was examined .

CARDINAL . ORG rejected the appeal in a summary fashion , finding that there was no reason to place the authenticity of the evidence in doubt and that there were no breaches of procedural norms . With regard to the witnesses , ORG held as follows :

“ The [ District ] court had no reason not to rely on the statements of the witnesses who were police officers , including witness P. ; their statements were assessed in court and found to be consistent , mutually complementary and compatible with other materials in the file . There is no indication that anyone has a vested interest in the criminal prosecution of the persons convicted . ”
